question.title: Gradle - "no main manifest attribute" in sample project
question.body:
I'm currently taking my first steps in Java and Gradle. When I run gradle init and choose application, Gradle generates a simple hello world sample. I can build it, but when I try to run java -jar app/build/libs/App.jar I get the error no main manifest attribute, in app/build/libs/app.jar. The manifest file inside the jar is indeed empty (except for the line Manifest-Version: 1.0).

I did find out, that I need to set the main class in Gradles build script, but the sample project already contains that setting. This is the complete build script that was generated by gradle. I haven't made any changes.

/*
 * This file was generated by the Gradle 'init' task.
 *
 * This generated file contains a sample Java application project to get you started.
 * For more details on building Java & JVM projects, please refer to https://docs.gradle.org/8.14.3/userguide/building_java_projects.html in the Gradle documentation.
 */

plugins {
    // Apply the application plugin to add support for building a CLI application in Java.
    application
}

repositories {
    // Use Maven Central for resolving dependencies.
    mavenCentral()
}

dependencies {
    // Use JUnit Jupiter for testing.
    testImplementation(libs.junit.jupiter)

    testRuntimeOnly("org.junit.platform:junit-platform-launcher")

    // This dependency is used by the application.
    implementation(libs.guava)
}

// Apply a specific Java toolchain to ease working on different environments.
java {
    toolchain {
        languageVersion = JavaLanguageVersion.of(21)
    }
}

application {
    // Define the main class for the application.
    mainClass = "org.example.App"
}

tasks.named<Test>("test") {
    // Use JUnit Platform for unit tests.
    useJUnitPlatform()
}

I can run the project using gradlew run. I assume, it uses the tar and zip files that are generated in addition to the jar file. Those contain a run script that start java and specify the main class in the command line. But I hope there is a way to get a regular executable jar file.

answers.body:
This part in your Gradle build script:

application {
    // Define the main class for the application.
    mainClass = "org.example.App"
}

Unfortunately does not automatically set the Main-Class attribute in the main JAR's manifest. Do the following to set the attribute (Kotlin DSL):

tasks.jar {
    manifest.attributes("Main-Class" to application.mainClass.get())
}

That's implemented to take the main class name from the application extension to share the configuration, but you can use any valid value you want.
